title: Measuring Pavement Condition in Developing Countries: The World Bank's Experience
segmentation: Good morning, one of the problems trying with the World Bank is you pick up all sorts of bugs and I picked up a cold last week so my apologies if I'm slightly hoarse.
People often wonder why is the World Bank involved with roads?
Well, guess was over 25 years ago.
We started working with the HDM model.
In fact the presentation on the road condition this morning from Slovenia was interesting.
Look at the report in 86 when the YRI produced was introduced by the World Bank.
You see it says less than two IR IR runways and airport pavements.
So the Slovenian roads are as good as airport pavements.
Based on what we did 20 years ago so have a good Rd network here.
We all know that data are essential element to any road management system without without knowing what you have and what condition it's in, you really can't make decisions.
And so when we try and help our countries to improve the management and operations of the road network map.
During Rd condition putting in place management systems is a core element of what the World Bank does.

Now, one of the challenges that we face is guiding countries in what data to collect, and this might seem quite straightforward to you, but the but one of the biggest challenges is gay people to collect what they need.
A few years ago we had a UK vendor who sold ground penetrating radar services, go to one of our countries and they did a full 5000 kilometres survey of pavement layer thickness.
We went to the client afterwards and they said what do we do with all this data?

They had piles of CD's and they had no use for it whatsoever, and this was an example where what they really needed was thickness where they did the FWD deflections, but they were just drowned in data.
And so it's a real challenge for us sometimes to steer the agencies to collecting just the right sort of data which they require.
Now, many of you know Bill Patterson, who by the way finally retired from the World Bank in July of this year, but he's now back as a consultant.
And yeah, when you retire, you just continue working with that.
Title in a higher salary.

He about in 1992 him and Thomas Scully and come up with this idea of information quality levels and the whole idea is that many of the technologies which we have can measure with high precision at very small intervals.
We had the example today of using 20 metre IRRI in the performance penalty payments but by the same token you can use less precise data, more general data to make decisions.
And that's the idea behind IQLIQ.
L1 is very detailed, very precise IQ of five is very general.
Now for those of you from the states, you probably recognize where this is.
This is the White House and courtesy of Google Earth.
This, to me summarizes the IQL concept in a nutshell.
The top left hand side you have top right hand side Washington decent from high up.
As you zoom down to get more and more detail till yet finally small scale you can make a decision to manage your roads based on any of these three levels.
But the problem is often people are thinking only with a small scale and that of course has implications for cost and management.
Now I've got 2 examples here for a practical way of how we did it in our projects in about 3 years ago in Cambodia.
We.

It network surveys of 11,000 kilometres of the entire Rd network and in this in this example here you can see they measured roughness over 100 meters because the roads are pretty rough in some places and they use an index called the Service Integrity Index which Bill came up with about 90 three, which basically is a scale from zero to five and then good fair failed for different aspects of the drainage condition.
This is what we call IQ L3 now another country.
Excuse me.
Is Timor leste?
Which is the West part of the island of Timor, which you may recall about 10 years ago?
There was a slight civil war between them and Indonesia, and when we went in there for rapid assessment.
We basically drove the roads and said good, fair or poor.
Now as you can see this is much easier.
In the previous slide and we could still make a nice decision based upon this.
Of course the error is much greater, but you still could make a decision quickly and easily.
Now the second challenge we face is to use the right technology now, as many of you know, vendors included technology designed for rose like this, but we survey roads like this.
The Middle Rd is actually.
Believe it or not, in Laos it is part of the National Highway and so one of the challenges you face is you can have the right intention but the wrong technology.
In 90 three I worked in India as a consultant and we had procured a profilometer vehicle.
To do network surveys on three on 4 States and the basic problem was it was accelerometer based system.
So do the signal to noise ratio.
It couldn't measurable 50 kilometres an hour now and have been to India.
Note there's a lot of roads.
You can't drive more than 50 kilometres an hour because of the people like in the bottom left side here.
So about 35% of the road network had no roughness data.
Just because the wrong technology was used.
This is also from the survey in Cambodia.
This is a paved Rd network.
Unlike Slovenia, you see 20% of the network is above 8 IRRI, and so with some of the more precise measurement systems they just don't work very well.
Such high roughness is, and so you sometimes need to use a blend of technologies to handle the range of road conditions.
Have another slide which shows the unsealed Rd roughness is which are right off the chart.
So what do we do at the World Bank were bank we give out money.
That's where it starts and ends in some sense.
And the money is used to do two things.
We procure equipment.
In fact, I'd probably say that with the larger fine.
Answer of equipment anywhere in the world, like in the last six months, we've procured two profilometer vehicles in China alone, plus FWD's.
We also finance data collection services and come a bit more about this later on.
The results very mixed.
I've been to places in where we procured a $300,000 vehicle and is now parked out back of the Highway Department and a big tarpaulin with chickens on top.
They won't let me take a photograph, but it's there.
We've got other clients who use the technology better than places like New Zealand in Europe, and so there's a full range of experiences so some people say what about data collection services?
Once again we've had great experiences and the worst problems imaginable, so I guess like the country work in we have the full gamut.
Experiences.
So what are the problems that we face when procuring equipment the number?
One problem we have is the vendors who go knocking on the doors and convince clients that they need to buy this.

I was once in a country in Southeast Asia when the client handed me a request to procure a laser based deflection measurement system from Denmark and I said this isn't actually operationally says yeah, but they were here talking to us about it recently and this looks like a really good technology now I don't know if Slovenia is using laser based reflections yet, but Indonesia definitely should not be doing that.
This is one of the problems.
Because the technologies which we can successfully implement and sustain and developed an some developing countries just do not work in others.
The second problem we face is the data.
Don't meet the agencies needs.
We've had examples of this were in China, for example the pavement management system there expresses cracking in a very certain, very certain way that the Chinese way obviously.
And so if you bring in a system safe from the West which uses the SH, RP or other measures of cracking.
You then have a slight problem because it doesn't work in the payment management system, so you have a $300,000 video based cracking system which doesn't quite meet the needs.
The equipment doesn't work for local conditions.
I touched upon that before with the Cambodian slide.
Maintenance and calibration.
That's a big problem.

In some countries you have restrictions on importing parts for vehicles, so if you for example bring in a fully built up vehicle an you find you need to get a replacement for the transmission, it can have you down for three to six months.

That's one of the reasons why the bank we prefer systems which can use local vehicles, and if you if you want to bid for any vendors or here you'll find that the World Bank specifications are mentioned now.
Basically have that as a requirement.
Local support that's a big problem.
Often what you find is vendors have local agents who all they care about.
Adding a percentage and not giving any support and Lastly training.
Particularly 'cause if you train someone up very well, they're often hired by a consultant to go somewhere else, so these are real problems.
Two years ago we did a project looking at data Collection Technologies, Rd management, and one of the things that we tried to do.
It was done with Herardo flinch.
I don't live here yet from Virginia Tech and Hernandez.
Seminyak, from Chile is.

They looked at some multi criteria analysis to say alright, there's a there's a balance between the cost of purchase, the cost of operation in the data you get and based upon this they came up with this framework which we basically have been looking to say.
Don't just look at the cost.
Look at the performance and everything else.
Now the grayed out bottom area on the slide.
If someone one of our clients want to pick your equipment in this area, it goes through very smoothly.

Anything outside of that, they've got a really convinced us because what we're saying is that my experience, the cost, or operational implications make it a challenge for that equipment to be used successfully.
Now the second problem we face is specifications because firstly the bank doesn't write specifications, they're done by a client agencies.
As you can imagine, these people often have very limited experience.
They just told we need to collect data often by the World Bank and they have to then make a decision.
And so they don't really understand the technologies with implications an what often happens.
Vendors influence the process.

They basically go to a client and say here's our specification and we suddenly find you know this looks remarkably familiar to product AB or C, and we pull up the manufacture specifications and identical, which unfortunately against the banks procurement guidelines.
And so there's a real problem where they also may miss important things.
So what do we do?
Well, we've recently about a year and a half ago released generic specifications.
We started off with the FWD and if anyone is here from the four manufacturers.
Thanks for your help.
We essentially hired against consultant, excuse me.
Who developed specifications?
We then sent them out and we said to the vendors.
OK, can you bid for this other words?
We didn't want something in there which was you gave one manufacture unique advantage over another one?
We allowed scope for differentiation, but basically we didn't want them saying it had to be a certain type of load cell or something else which we sometimes see.
We then did that for weigh in motion and traffic volume.
And for multifunction vehicles like laser profilometers and videos and so the specifications contain.

Two part, there's the technical specifications, but also a description as to why is this important, because often we found the clients weren't giving up Information Center Rd network on the fact that it snows for five months of the year and therefore you can only survey under these conditions.
You can download these net website uptheirrdmanagement.info and any feedback would be most appreciated.
There's a couple of key principles which are in these specifications or come about through experience, how we say.
Wanna prob?
What we had was that some of our clients received equipments and two.

Them off the ship and started using them and found that actually they were giving wrong results, although I also observed this in Toronto, Canada once we're looking at the Ministry of Transportation, Ontario's database so.
The first step we have them do is do a calibration to show the measurements work.
We then validate to show they work in local conditions because again, not all systems are developed for the pavements and the conditions are operated under those.
One problem in one of our countries where it was 35 degrees Centigrade in the vehicle, air conditioning wasn't working and the guys couldn't actually do surveys 'cause the computer shutting down.
So we said sorry, you've got a retrofit heavier air conditioning to the vehicle and we won't pay for it.
But then the next thing is 100 kilometers sample survey.

Why well, essentially we have the vendor go out with the client and show it actually works, collect the data and it's surprising how often during the survey something breaks on the vehicle which requires the vendor to again fix.
Previously the vendors came in, they said here's your vehicle or your whatever piece of equipment and then it broke down very shortly afterwards.
The Third Point, load the data in the road management system.
Again, this shows that the data is actually usable by the client in more than one project.
The format from the vendors was inconsistent with the format used by the highway agency.

It could still go in, but required a bit of manipulation, so we now require that whatever you supply better FWD or grip tester or a profilometer, the data can go into the role management system and only then do you get paid.
So this is now a requirement for the bank procurement process and it's come about because we've had so many problems in the past with our various countries.
So for that reason it was mentioned earlier on there's a trend towards data collection services because.
The theory is.
This will go better.

We did a review of called SuccessFactors Rd Management Systems where we interviewed people in 21 agencies in different countries and we found that even those who had gone to data collection services still had problems and one of the reasons was that if you go to the data collection services it alters the skill demands from the client.
You now require the ability to manage the contract very well.
If there's some way of actually checking the data that you're getting because you're paying against it, but importantly, you need to make sure there's liquidated damages for poor performance.
In other words, if the contractor doesn't doesn't work, it cost them money, not you.
The biggest challenge we face is costing this thing now.
I pulled these numbers out and they're fairly accurate.
You can see here the range of cost per kilometer are an order of.

Fourfold from New Zealand where they can do 300 kilometers a day to Philippines with 42 islands, and so it's a real challenge because when you're trying to estimate the budget for these sort of assignments, you don't have a good grip for us.
Going to cost, even for similar surveys and similar countries.
So what we've tended to do is to recommend a core network of, say, two 3000 kilometers, and then optional additional surveys based upon the costs.
But this is one of the biggest challenges that you will face if you go this route.
So while these costs are variable, well I like this second from the bottom one.
Banditry that is people coming out to try and create problems for you.
We were, we financed.
Bridge survey in the Papua New Guinea, and when you read the reports, it's quite amusing.
Sometimes they say the police wouldn't take us on this road to survey, it was too dangerous for them or we were serving this bridge.
But people came with guns so we didn't finish the survey, so it's a real issue here.
In fact, in Laos few years ago, the survey crew got arrested for three days and they got near the Vietnam border, and so you have real challenges.
And so when preparing for these surveys, people price in risk, and that's one of the reasons you get such a huge variation.
But these are exceptional countries.
So what are the challenges that you face?
Well, firstly the sheer volume of data these days profilometers, particularly looking at those with image crack detection generate.
Gigabytes or terabytes of data?
Now one of the things we learned early on was that can't.
Tractors would sometimes just collect the data and then postprocess it afterwards.
That was a recipe for disaster, and so because what happened was there was so much data that clients often didn't get the results for over a year after the surveys were done.
So now we basically say must be done within 30 days of surveys.
Quality assurance cannot be underestimated in the Philippines.
My function said the Philippines in one country.
The contractor had such poor quality control.
They submit data, it was wrong.
Went back to them four Times Now if you can imagine an agency having to check the same data four times when there's more data coming from 25,000 kilometres of roads, it's just.
It's just crazy and universally they all underestimated the difficulties in data processing.
So just because you're going to contract out data doesn't mean your life is going to be easier.
Now this is an example from six months ago.
In a country in East Asia, I won't say where and they procured someone to do a GPS.
Center line this is the results of the data that was submitted and you can see here this works.
Yes, you can see here.
These roads go nowhere.
This supposed to be connected.
This actually a Rd which goes along here and so you can see the very poor quality.
This was submitted by a consultant to the agency to use for their Rd management system and this is not unusual.
I've got lots of examples of this.
So as a result, we've developed a generic terms of reference for data collection services, and this is again designed to take the agency through the procurement process what?
The problems you're likely to face.
How can you fix those as well as minimum specifications for data collection, appropriateness and the key quality assurance?
One of the changes we've used is in the past.
The bank made some big mistakes with these.
We use them as a consulting service assignment, which meant people were paid on inputs and as you can imagine, if you're sending data four times, you go through a lot of man months of time.
Now it's pure output based.
You've given a small amount for your initial calibration data acceptance, and that's per kilometer for data approved.
That way the risk is now transferred over from the client to the contractor.
One of the things which we've also tried to do is to make it very clear.
Spectate
We we defined them here as mandatory optional anatra
Quired, because sometimes you can have a missionary on you.
Do a core set of requirements.
Requires a roughness and inventory.
But the other pricey optional data items and an extra service.
That way if you can afford it, you increase the scope of works.
Quality assurance you've got to do it.
In fact it's got to the point now where we're trying a separate consulting assignment for quality assurance on the data, because it's just such an issue.
Disney and this is an example of the Philippines where they put in place a good quality assurance program after the earlier problems they had.
Sort of close.
One of the issues that we've learned for Rd management systems data Collection is a convergence is often in the past.
We focus on technology.
Let's get the right.
Falling weight.

Deflect amature the right profilometer, but we've missed the fact that without the people in the agency or the consultancy to use the data or the process is to ensure the data collection is correct, it it falls apart.
So when all these three converge, then you have a successful system which gives you information that you can use.
Thank you.
